data.text:
@johndefeo @BolognaFishMD "Deaths will depend on demographics, co-morbidity prevalence, the use of therapeutics*, __vaccination rates__.."

I.e. two years ago the vaccination rate was ZERO. Having a large number of cases now is not the same as having a large number of cases then, in whatever category

@johndefeo @BolognaFishMD This was the Zero-COVID strategy of New Zealand, where Zero-COVID was clearly stated as an interim strategy to allow vaccine rollout. I do not see the growth of cases after vaccinations took place as a failure of the interim strategy. https://t.co/OVT5zpXAsu

@Marco_Piani @BolognaFishMD *The existence of previously-unavailable therapeutics is one of the last (less spoken) justifications for support of zero-COVID strategies, but it hardly seems sensical when at-risk populations have had more that a year to get vaccinated and vax campaigns targeted low-risk.

2/2

@Marco_Piani @BolognaFishMD I don't see the benefit in sharing cumulative deaths resulting from surges that had not yet occurred. The dam is now breaking on zero-COVID strategies. Deaths will depend on demographics, co-morbidity prevalence, the use of therapeutics,* etc.

1/2

@BolognaFishMD @johndefeo They strangely always show plots of exploding cases and not cumulative deaths, even if for a while many people used to say "cases do not count; only deaths count" https://t.co/0wzvnc13td
@laylag2 @johndefeo @DrJBhattacharya could this have anything to do with kpop?
@johndefeo You do realize that now we have vaccines while we did not have them in 2020, right?
